11:12 am
BE11:13am

Sirius Minerals financing risks have materialized, which presents a significant risk to the proportion of equity ownership within EV, in our opinion. SXX has announced this morning that the proposed US$500m senior secured notes offering cannot be delivered in the current market environment (target B/B- rating). As such, the Stage 2 funding plan to raise US$3bn has been abandoned, the US$2.5bn revolving credit facility (RCF) will lapse at the end of October, and US$400m of CBs held in escrow will be released to issuers. SXX has indicated it will now slow the pace of development to key areas of the project to “preserve the most value”, while a 6mth strategic review is conducted to assess available options going forward, including: 1) optimising development plan; 2) revising development plan; 3) alternative financing arrangement; and 4) strategic investor. SXX has total cash of £180m or
£117m post commitments, which the company believes provides sufficient liquidity over the review period. We understand prior project metrics, including timeframe for first ore (previously H2’21) are now subject to change. T

FATDAZ @REF lol but nicely summed up I feel
BE11:13am

Financing plan abandoned: SXX announced this morning that the proposed offering of the US$500m senior secured note is now unlikely to be achievable in compliance with the terms of the US$2.5bn RCF. A key issue was HY investors had indicated a preference for equity-linked products (i.e. warrants) as part of the offering, which would take the overall ‘all-in’ yield greater than 15%, which is above terms of the RCF (yield limit was to mitigate HY refinancing risk). As such, the Stage 2 funding plan to raise US$3bn has been abandoned, the US$2.5bn RCF will lapse at the end of October, and US$400m of CBs held in escrow will be released to issuers. Further conversations with the Government have also been unsuccessful.

BE11:13am

Strategic review initiated: Concurrently, SXX has indicated it will slow the pace of development to key areas of the project to “preserve the most value”, whilst a 6mth strategic review is conducted to assess available options going forward. The key areas that the strategic review will assess include 1) optimising development plan (i.e. optimized shaft boring, tunnel boring etc.); 2) revising development plan (i.e. phasing areas of project with higher construction risk); 3) alternative financing arrangement; and 4) strategic investor. SXX has total cash of £180m or £117m post commitments, which SXX believes provides sufficient liquidity over the review period.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

Material negative for equity ownership: We had previously indicated that equity-holders were shouldering a high level of financing risk and this would prohibit a re-rating until the HY tranche was finalised (here). We now see two significant risks to equity ownership within EV going forward. Firstly, the market will clearly price in either further equity calls from investors and/or reduction in ownership via a strategic sell-down in the asset base (at a discount to NPV). Secondly, project metrics used to underpin valuation models (e.g. first ore, operating costs etc) are now subject to change, which means inherent risks with a DCF-based approach.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Shore:

BE11:18am

Sirius Minerals released bad news this morning: the company is not going ahead with its proposed US$500m Initial Bond (IB) issuance due to ongoing poor bond market conditions.

According to Sirius, feedback from investors was that the offering could succeed if warrants were included in the offering. The stumbling block was that one of the conditions of the US$2.5bn Revolving Credit Facility (RCF) stipulates a maximum all-in effective yield for the IBs of 15% - which would be exceeded by the expected returns of the warrants. Sirius therefore requested a waiver of this condition, but JP Morgan declined to play ball. Sirius now intends to terminate the RCF commitment “in the coming days”.
Despite positive noises, when push came to shove, UK government support has not been forthcoming. Sirius requested a commitment to enable the issue of up to US$1bn of guaranteed bonds (i.e. the UK government would provide a guarantee, not actual funding) in the event it was unable to issue unguaranteed bonds for RCF refinancing. This is despite Sirius proposing that any such bonds would only be issued after at least 18 more months’ development activity (to reduce execution risks) and up to an additional US$2bn having already been invested in the project.
The US$400m of Stage 2 convertible bond proceeds being held in escrow will be returned to investors, in light of the above. Around US$240m of non-escrow and Stage 1 convertible bonds will remain outstanding.
Sirius will now reduce the pace of development at its paradigm-shifting North Yorkshire polyhalite project in England, focusing activity on key areas that will preserve the most value for the project. The company had £180m of unrestricted cash reserves as of 31st August 2019 (of which £117m was uncommitted), which it believes will provide sufficient liquidity to explore alternative financing solutions over a period of up to six months (potentially including a strategic partner).

There is also potential to incorporate further optimisations to the project development plan. In particular, with note that tunnelling rates on Drive 1 have been faster than expected (already averaging 17m/day – the ostensible target - despite the current ground being relatively difficult; the fastest rate achieved to date is 29.5m/day), potentially removing the need for a tunnel boring machine (TBM) at Lockwood Beck. Additionally, there is potential to use the TBM mucking system to transport up to 6Mtpa of polyhalite during tunnel fitout, thereby accelerating commercial production.

Irish HF guy S&P at all time high (nearly) and market conditions to blame, I always laugh at that. I think they mean, valuation expectations or yield considerations for Wework and Sirius. @PBateman, agreed. A lot of locals invested in Sirius.
BE11:18am

Liberum:

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Sirius has announced it does not believe it will be able to issue $500m bonds in the current market environment, resulting in the lapse of the RCF and its current stage 2 financing plans. Alternative proposals which included exploring an export credit guarantee or attaching warrants to the bond issue were rejected by the government and JPM respectively. The company has £180m in cash of which c.£100m is uncommitted, giving it around 6 months to find a financing solution. Its unclear whether the lack of appetite for its bonds was a function of project specific risks, market conditions or a combination of both, but as a result a capital markets led financing solution seems unlikely, leaving the only feasible financing options being via government guaranteed bonds or a strategic investor with a balance sheet. Without a clear path to financing we place our target price under review.

BE11:29am

Summary from the release and conference call: Business as usual – Retail continues to grow quickly and Zoom trials continue to show signs of strong progress like in H1. However it is worth reminding ourselves: UK grocery is growing at ~0.5%, discounters at ~+7.5% … and Ocado is outgrowing all of them at +11.4% despite the impact of a fire.
Q1 Retail sales of £386.3m (+11.4% YoY) was well within the guided 10-15% range although a touch shy of Bernstein estimate of +12.5%. Unlike the UK grocery sector, Ocado is more immune to swings in weather, royal weddings or world-cups (OCDO doesn’t really see the swings up, nor down). Orders per week (OPW) grew +12.1% YoY to 314k. Basket size fell - 0.8% YoY to £105.42 but in line with Ocado's longer term expectations of around -0.5%.
Capacity constraints still there. Additional capacity available in Erith from the Morrisons temporary holiday helped to meet new demand, although on the call Ocado highlighted that they are still feeling some of the effects of the Andover fire in Q1, during which they stopped marketing for new customers as they chose to instead service existing customers by spreading demand across the week. Those new customers would have spent more now. CFC 5 (Purfleet) has since secured planning permission and is expected to go live in ~2 years.
New Retail JV: A new CEO has been appointed to lead the JV (Melanie Smith). Key focus appears to be on expanding the M&S full food range which today is lacking. The end goal for the JV is to have an offering that is at least as good as what they have today.
Solutions: Ocado said they continue to work well with existing partners and are in discussions with new partners. Nothing new.
Zoom: Like in H1, continues to support Ocado's conviction that partners, including the JV, will be able to use this technology. Basket sizes, quality of offering, and lead times (30-60 mins, closer to 30) have been maintained as they grow volumes.

BE11:35am

Kroger’s 5 November CMD comes at a time when the US grocer has identified four CFC sites (a fifth mid-Atlantic location has still not been specified). Which strikes us as a fairly slow rate of roll-out in the context of Kroger's initial commitment to 20 CFCs. Bottom line a strong acceleration in the rate of CFC announcements needs to materialise in order to support our estimated NPV of c. £1.5bn for the 38 sites already globally committed to the Ocado Smart Platform. This, in turn, would likely have some material consequences for both KR's mid-term capex and margin trajetory. In early November KR will have the opportunity to engage more fully with the Street on these details, with no clear guidance provided by the group since the initial 2018 announcement.

Critical to the future
shape of the US online grocery market was WMT's announcement last week of what
looks to us as an aggressive level of pricing for its 'Delivery Unlimited' pass at $98/ year or $12.95/month (vs regular delivery at $9.99 and free store pick-up). A very keen Minimum Basket Size of $30 will apply. Delivery services Instacart and Shipt both price at $99/year (Instacart recently cut its price from $149), with a $35 MBS. Amazon Fresh is substantially more expensive at c.$180/year on top of $99 Prime (see charts for more context, including Ocado Retail). Fulfilled from stores, this WMT offering will cover 1,600 locations and 50% of the population by the end of 2019.

We remain of the view that OCDO’s worth is inextricably linked to the financial robustness of the OSP to its clients, rather than the theoretical returns profile to Ocado on currently disclosed terms. Our chief concern is that benchmarking OCDO clients’ potential returns on Ocado’s margin profile of its centrally-picked UK retail business would be misleading, given the latter’s aspirational appeal (which boosts the mix of margin) and the ideal population distribution and topography of England.

Help to Buy was originally intended as a short-lived scheme but will now last for 10 years and consume over 8 times its original budget, yet the value achieved from its extension is uncertain. Around three-fifths of buyers who took part in the scheme did not need its support to buy a property, and the large sums of money tied up could have been spent in different ways to address a wider set of housing priorities and focus more on those most in need. The early scheme achieved its own aims to support people into home ownership, and boost the housing market. The scheme does not address issues with the wider planning system, or other problems in housing, such as the provision of affordable housing to buy or to rent and rising levels of homelessness, nor was it designed to do so.
The Department has other programmes to address these issues, but Help to Buy remains its largest initiative by value. The Department acknowledges that the scheme has, however, only benefitted one section of society—those that are in a position to buy their own home in the first place.
Inherent uncertainty in the housing market means there are still risks to the Department achieving a positive return on its investment in homes. The new scheme from 2021 provides an opportunity to target the money more effectively, but the Department has not yet fully thought out how it will do this. Unless the Department plans alternative housing initiatives, the end of the scheme in 2023 may lead to a fall in supply, adding to the challenge it already faces in achieving its ambition of 300,000 homes a year from the mid-2020s.

BE12:00pm

.... here's a Barclays thing about Norwegian, the Ocado of air travel.

BE12:00pm

The sagaof European long-haul, low-cost carrierscontinues with Norwegian Airlines recently catching another break with an extension of its December bond maturity. While cash-strapped airlines are nothing new, the outlook for Norwegian is loaded with implicationsfor the industry. With help from a rights offering earlierthis year, aircraft salesand now an extension ofits bond maturity, Norwegian has so far navigateda stretched balance sheet. However, with continued losses, management is restructuring the business, pulling back growthand reducingcosts, which could proveeven more challenging with fuel prices ontherise.Regardless of the outcome, we think Norwegian’s challenges likely translate to a more favorable operating environmentfor other carrierseven assuminga successful operational restructuring.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Outlook for Norwegian remains uncertain. Despitenear-term help from abond maturity extension,Norwegian continues to incur losses, which could again become amplified movingout of the peak summer travel season. However, the grounding of Boeing 737 MAXaircraft, which initially represented more than 10% of the carrier’s 2019 capacity, could ultimately helpdelaycapex and createflexibility for the carrier to defer upcoming deliveries. Further, Norwegian could also receive cash compensation from BoeingandRolls Royce due to prior787 engine operational issues, whichcould provide further liquidity during the carrier’s operational restructuring.

Low-cost, long-haul model could be running out of steam in Trans-Atlantic; Norwegian capacity down meaningfully in 4Q19.Severallong-haul, low-cost leisure focused carriers such asWow havestruggled, but Norwegian still maintains nearly 7% of capacity between the US and Europe. After several years of elevated growth, current schedules show Norwegian's US-Europe 4Q19 capacity declining roughly 20%.Nonetheless, we are left questioning the sustainabilityof the long-haul, low-cost model relative to the scale, efficiencyand connectivityofmajornetwork carriers’ global alliances and JVs.Norwegian’s expansion within Europe also set to slow. WhileNorwegian currently maintains roughly 4% of capacity of the intra-European markets, the carrier’sgrowth likely has not been as disruptive as its expansion across the Atlantic. Nonetheless, current schedules indicate 4Q19 capacity decliningroughly 20% in intra-European markets, due to narrow-body aircraft sales and the grounding of the MAX.Norwegian maintains a small share in other markets including 2% of capacity between Europe and Latin America and less than 1% in Europe-Asia markets.WhileNorwegian maintains a relatively small share in Latin American and Asian markets, the carrier’soperations are primarily focused in Argentina and Thailand.

It is early days but Pennsylvania (PA) appears to be adopting sports betting at a promising pace. In August, PA total wagering represented almost 40% of the equivalent New Jersey (NJ) figure (and was some distance ahead of where its neighbour was 12 months ago). Several familiar trends are apparent in the August NJ data as well. The data from the US therefore continues to be encouraging. All eyes are now on September data in both states, when the impact of the NFL season (and a more established competitive environment in NJ) will be clearer.
